page.title: Timeline of the 2011 Egyptian revolution under Hosni Mubarak's rule

rev.diff:
Line 285: Line 285:
[[File:Tahrir Square - February 10, 2011.png|thumb|Over 2 millions protesting in [[Tahrir Square]] on February 10, 2011 after [[Hosni Mubarak]]'s speech saying that they'll go to his palace the day after.]]
[[File:Tahrir Square - February 10, 2011.png|thumb|Over 2 millions protesting in [[Tahrir Square]] on February 10, 2011 after [[Hosni Mubarak]]'s speech saying that they'll go to his palace the day after.]]
[[File:People demand removal of the regime Tahrir.JPG|thumb|Banner on Tahrir Square on 12 February.]]
[[File:People demand removal of the regime Tahrir.JPG|thumb|Banner on Tahrir Square on 12 February.]]
â
The protests continued at Tahrir Square and the parliament building. 3,000 lawyers marched from the lawyers' syndicate in downtown Cairo to [[Abdeen Palace]], one of the official residences of the president. About a thousand physicians, dressed in white coats, also arrived at Tahrir Square to applause.<ref name="aljazbloglive10feb">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/09/live-blog-feb-10-egypt-protests< |title=Live Blog Feb 10 â Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera]] |date= |accessdate=10 February 2011}}</ref> Strikes at national industries, including tourism and transportation, continued<ref name="VOA-20110210">{{cite news|url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/middle-east/Protests-Strikes-Spread-as-Egypts-Regime-Stiffens-115706904.html|title=Protests, Strikes Spread as Egypt's Regime Stiffens|publisher=[[Voice of America]]|date=February 10, 2011|accessdate=February 10, 2011}}</ref> and even spread to Alexandria, Mahalla and Port Said.<ref name="aljazlive">[[Al Jazeera English]]: Breaking News, 2011</ref>{{Full|February 2011}} Protesters around Egypt, who were expecting Mubarak to announce his resignation,
+
The protests continued at Tahrir Square and the parliament building. 3,000 lawyers marched from the lawyers' syndicate in downtown Cairo to [[Abdeen Palace]], one of the official residences of the president. About a thousand physicians, dressed in white coats, also arrived at Tahrir Square to applause.<ref name="aljazbloglive10feb">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/09/live-blog-feb-10-egypt-protests< |title=Live Blog Feb 10 â Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera]] |date= |accessdate=10 February 2011}}</ref> Strikes at national industries, including tourism and transportation, continued<ref name="VOA-20110210">{{cite news|url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/middle-east/Protests-Strikes-Spread-as-Egypts-Regime-Stiffens-115706904.html|title=Protests, Strikes Spread as Egypt's Regime Stiffens|publisher=[[Voice of America]]|date=February 10, 2011|accessdate=February 10, 2011}}</ref> and even spread to Alexandria, Mahalla and Port Said.{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}} Protesters around Egypt, who were expecting Mubarak to announce his resignation,
â
were described as euphoric, while singing and waving Egyptian flags.<ref>({{citation|url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5iEz31PZvDAAwis44KBhmha7EBxZw?docId=947212c1ab074fbe9513c7f6791a339a|title=Expecting Mubarak to go, protest camp euphoric|publisher=AFP}}</ref> Fighter aircraft were heard above the Tahrir Square at 20:00 amid calls for the "destruction of the regime." In Alexandria, over a 1,000 "diehard" protesters were reported by the train station.<ref name="aljazlive" />
+
were described as euphoric, while singing and waving Egyptian flags.<ref>({{citation|url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5iEz31PZvDAAwis44KBhmha7EBxZw?docId=947212c1ab074fbe9513c7f6791a339a|title=Expecting Mubarak to go, protest camp euphoric|publisher=AFP}}</ref> Fighter aircraft were heard above the Tahrir Square at 20:00 amid calls for the "destruction of the regime." In Alexandria, over a 1,000 "diehard" protesters were reported by the train station.{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}}
â
Prior to Mubarak's speech, contradictory reports from various media sources around the world stated that either Suleiman or Tantawi was expected to take over.<ref>[http://www.globes.co.il/news/article.aspx?did=1000622357 ××¦×¨×× ×××¨× ×××©××¨ ×¦×××? ×××××¨×§ ×¦×¤×× ×××ª×¤××¨ ××¢×¨×],Israel's [[Globes]] newspaper, 2 February 2011</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Fam |first=Mariam |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-10/mubarak-may-resign-before-september-egyptian-ruling-party-official-says.html |title=Egypt's President Mubarak May Step Down as Army Meets |publisher=Bloomberg |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref> The military council also met without Mubarak.<ref name="aljazlive" /> The Muslim Brotherhood had feared a coup at one point. Even though celebrations had begun at Tahrir Square before the statement, the head of the NDP said that Mubarak should go for the good of the country.<ref name="aljazlive" />
+
Prior to Mubarak's speech, contradictory reports from various media sources around the world stated that either Suleiman or Tantawi was expected to take over.<ref>[http://www.globes.co.il/news/article.aspx?did=1000622357 ××¦×¨×× ×××¨× ×××©××¨ ×¦×××? ×××××¨×§ ×¦×¤×× ×××ª×¤××¨ ××¢×¨×],Israel's [[Globes]] newspaper, 2 February 2011</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Fam |first=Mariam |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-10/mubarak-may-resign-before-september-egyptian-ruling-party-official-says.html |title=Egypt's President Mubarak May Step Down as Army Meets |publisher=Bloomberg |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref> The military council also met without Mubarak.{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}} The Muslim Brotherhood had feared a coup at one point. Even though celebrations had begun at Tahrir Square before the statement, the head of the NDP said that Mubarak should go for the good of the country.{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}}
[[Al Hurra]] TV reported that Mubarak was planning to hand his authorities to the Egyptian army.<ref>{{he}}[[Ehud Yaari]], [[Israeli News Company]], [[Channel 2 (Israel)]] [http://www.mako.co.il/news-world/arab/Article-a084cdc90101e21004.htm ×××××¨×§ ××¢×××¨ ××ª ×¡××××××ª×× ××¦××]</ref> General Hassan al-Roueini, the military commander for the Cairo area, told protesters in Tahrir Square, "All your demands will be met today."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA0CHO0.html |title=Military says Mubarak will meet protesters demands |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref> State TV added that Mubarak will speak tonight from his Cairo palace. This came after Egypt's military proclaimed on television that they have stepped in to "safeguard the country". The ''Associated Press'' suggested a military coup may be occurring. State TV showed Defence Minster [[Field Marshal]] Mohamed Hussein Tantawi meeting with two dozen top army officers. Mubarak and his vice president, Omar Suleiman were not present.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA1S980.html |title=Mubarak meets with VP, protesters flood square |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref>
[[Al Hurra]] TV reported that Mubarak was planning to hand his authorities to the Egyptian army.<ref>{{he}}[[Ehud Yaari]], [[Israeli News Company]], [[Channel 2 (Israel)]] [http://www.mako.co.il/news-world/arab/Article-a084cdc90101e21004.htm ×××××¨×§ ××¢×××¨ ××ª ×¡××××××ª×× ××¦××]</ref> General Hassan al-Roueini, the military commander for the Cairo area, told protesters in Tahrir Square, "All your demands will be met today."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA0CHO0.html |title=Military says Mubarak will meet protesters demands |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref> State TV added that Mubarak will speak tonight from his Cairo palace. This came after Egypt's military proclaimed on television that they have stepped in to "safeguard the country". The ''Associated Press'' suggested a military coup may be occurring. State TV showed Defence Minster [[Field Marshal]] Mohamed Hussein Tantawi meeting with two dozen top army officers. Mubarak and his vice president, Omar Suleiman were not present.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA1S980.html |title=Mubarak meets with VP, protesters flood square |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref>
Line 297: Line 297:
In his television statement, Mubarak said that he would penalise those responsible for the violence and has a clear vision on how to end the crisis, but is satisfied with what he has offered. He stated that while remaining president to the end of his term in September he would transfer his powers to vice-president [[Omar Suleiman]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Shahine |first=Alaa |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-10/mubarak-ignores-calls-for-ouster-delegates-authority-to-egypt-s-suleiman.html |title=Mubarak Defiance of Ouster Calls Angers Protesters |publisher=Bloomberg |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA55F03.html |title=Egypt's Mubarak transfers power to vice president |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref> As far as the transfer of power is concerned, Mubarak said "I have seen that it is required to delegate the powers and authorities of the president to the vice president as dictated in the constitution,". The constitutional article is used to transfer powers if the president is "temporarily" unable to carry out his duties and does not mean his resignation.<ref name="myway1">{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA5CEO2.html |title=Egypt's Mubarak transfers power to vice president |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref> He also said he will request six constitutional amendments and that he would lift emergency laws when security in the country permitted it.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA58F81.html |title=Egypt's Mubarak transfers power to vice president |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref> Mubarak also said he would stay in the country and is "adamant to continue to shoulder my responsibility to protect the constitution and safeguard the interests of the people ... until power is handed over to those elected in September by the people in free and fair elections in which all the guarantees of transparencies will be secured."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA5JD00.html |title=Egypt's Mubarak transfers power to vice president |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref>
In his television statement, Mubarak said that he would penalise those responsible for the violence and has a clear vision on how to end the crisis, but is satisfied with what he has offered. He stated that while remaining president to the end of his term in September he would transfer his powers to vice-president [[Omar Suleiman]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Shahine |first=Alaa |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-10/mubarak-ignores-calls-for-ouster-delegates-authority-to-egypt-s-suleiman.html |title=Mubarak Defiance of Ouster Calls Angers Protesters |publisher=Bloomberg |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA55F03.html |title=Egypt's Mubarak transfers power to vice president |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref> As far as the transfer of power is concerned, Mubarak said "I have seen that it is required to delegate the powers and authorities of the president to the vice president as dictated in the constitution,". The constitutional article is used to transfer powers if the president is "temporarily" unable to carry out his duties and does not mean his resignation.<ref name="myway1">{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA5CEO2.html |title=Egypt's Mubarak transfers power to vice president |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref> He also said he will request six constitutional amendments and that he would lift emergency laws when security in the country permitted it.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA58F81.html |title=Egypt's Mubarak transfers power to vice president |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref> Mubarak also said he would stay in the country and is "adamant to continue to shoulder my responsibility to protect the constitution and safeguard the interests of the people ... until power is handed over to those elected in September by the people in free and fair elections in which all the guarantees of transparencies will be secured."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA5JD00.html |title=Egypt's Mubarak transfers power to vice president |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref>
â
Protesters watched in stunned silence or in anger to his speech, some crying or waving their shoes in the air.<ref name="myway1"/> People in Tahrir Square chanted "Leave! Leave! Leave!" after Mubarak's speech.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://parkerspitzer.blogs.cnn.com/2011/02/10/mubarak-says-hes-staying-until-september/ |title=Mubarak says he's staying until September â Parker Spitzer - CNN.com Blogs |publisher=Parkerspitzer.blogs.cnn.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref> Vice President Omar Suleiman called on the anti-Mubarak protesters to go home.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA5RQO0.html |title=Egypt's Mubarak transfers power to vice president |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref> Protesters then moved to the state television and radio buildings.<ref name="aljazlive" /> Soon after the television announcement, a large number of protesters began to march towards the presidential palace<ref>{{cite web|url=http://online.wsj.com/article/BT-CO-20110210-719857.html |title=2nd UPDATE: Oil Gains; Stocks, Euro Fall; Mostly Calm On Egypt News - WSJ.com |publisher=Online.wsj.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref> Mohamed ElBaradei is saying "Egypt will explode" because Mubarak refused to step down. He also called on the military to intervene.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA71380.html |title=ElBaradei calls on Egyptian army to intervene |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref>
+
Protesters watched in stunned silence or in anger to his speech, some crying or waving their shoes in the air.<ref name="myway1"/> People in Tahrir Square chanted "Leave! Leave! Leave!" after Mubarak's speech.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://parkerspitzer.blogs.cnn.com/2011/02/10/mubarak-says-hes-staying-until-september/ |title=Mubarak says he's staying until September â Parker Spitzer - CNN.com Blogs |publisher=Parkerspitzer.blogs.cnn.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref> Vice President Omar Suleiman called on the anti-Mubarak protesters to go home.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA5RQO0.html |title=Egypt's Mubarak transfers power to vice president |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref> Protesters then moved to the state television and radio buildings.{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}} Soon after the television announcement, a large number of protesters began to march towards the presidential palace<ref>{{cite web|url=http://online.wsj.com/article/BT-CO-20110210-719857.html |title=2nd UPDATE: Oil Gains; Stocks, Euro Fall; Mostly Calm On Egypt News - WSJ.com |publisher=Online.wsj.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref> Mohamed ElBaradei is saying "Egypt will explode" because Mubarak refused to step down. He also called on the military to intervene.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA71380.html |title=ElBaradei calls on Egyptian army to intervene |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref>
Mubarak's top aides, family and son Gamal told him he could still ride out the turmoil. This is the reason that the televised resignation speech became a stubborn and humiliating effort to cling on to power.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110212/D9LBGH2O0.html |title=Mubarak's final hours: Desperate bids to stay |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-13}}</ref> It was also reported that Mubarak's other son, Alaa, accused his younger brother Gamal of ruining their father's reputation.<ref>{{cite web|last=Sabel |first=Robbie |url=http://www.jpost.com/MiddleEast/Article.aspx?id=208106 |title='Mubarak's sons nearly come to blows during speech' |publisher=Jpost.com |date=2011-02-14 |accessdate=2011-02-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://uk.news.yahoo.com/22/20110213/tpl-uk-egypt-mubarak-sons-4b8df73.html |title=Sons of Egypt's Mubarak nearly came to blows - report - Yahoo! News UK |publisher=Uk.news.yahoo.com |date=2010-01-01 |accessdate=2011-02-20}}</ref>
Mubarak's top aides, family and son Gamal told him he could still ride out the turmoil. This is the reason that the televised resignation speech became a stubborn and humiliating effort to cling on to power.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110212/D9LBGH2O0.html |title=Mubarak's final hours: Desperate bids to stay |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-13}}</ref> It was also reported that Mubarak's other son, Alaa, accused his younger brother Gamal of ruining their father's reputation.<ref>{{cite web|last=Sabel |first=Robbie |url=http://www.jpost.com/MiddleEast/Article.aspx?id=208106 |title='Mubarak's sons nearly come to blows during speech' |publisher=Jpost.com |date=2011-02-14 |accessdate=2011-02-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://uk.news.yahoo.com/22/20110213/tpl-uk-egypt-mubarak-sons-4b8df73.html |title=Sons of Egypt's Mubarak nearly came to blows - report - Yahoo! News UK |publisher=Uk.news.yahoo.com |date=2010-01-01 |accessdate=2011-02-20}}</ref>
Line 307: Line 307:
Shock that Mubarak did not step down on Thursday 10 February resulted in a nationwide escalation of protests on 11 February, named again as the '''"Friday of Departure"''' by the opposition movement.<ref name="signonsandiego1">{{cite news | last = Schemm | first = Paul | last2 = Michael | first2 = Maggie | agency = Associated Press | date = 2011-02-05 | url = http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/2011/feb/11/mubarak-leaves-cairo-for-sinai-as-protests-spread/ | title = Mubarak leaves Cairo for Sinai as protests spread | publisher = SignOnSanDiego.com | accessdate = 2011-02-12 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|publisher=Al Jazeera|title=Egypt's army vows smooth transition|date=February 12, 2011|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121217639448807.html|accessdate=February 13, 2011}}</ref> Massive protests continued in Cairo, Alexandria, and other cities. The presidential palace and parliament still remained surrounded by protestors and thousands of people surrounded the state TV building, keeping anyone from entering or leaving. The army issued a ''[[communiquÃ©]]'' in support of Mubarak's attempt to remain ''[[de jure]]'' president while delegating his powers to Vice President Suleiman.<ref>{{citation|title=Egyptian army backs Hosni Mubarak and calls for protesters to go home|ell by .25%url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/11/egyptian-army-backs-hosni-mubarak|first=Paul|last=Owen|date=2011/02/11|publisher=Guardian.co.uk}}</ref> Hossam Badrawi, the new secretary of the NDP, resigned from his position from the party due to his unhappiness with Hosni Mubarak's refusal to step down.<ref>[http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/02/11/latest-updates-on-day-18-of-egypt-protests/?hp "Latest Updates on Day 18 of Egypt Protests"] by Robert Mackey - ''The New York Times.'.' Retrieved 11 February 2011.</ref>
Shock that Mubarak did not step down on Thursday 10 February resulted in a nationwide escalation of protests on 11 February, named again as the '''"Friday of Departure"''' by the opposition movement.<ref name="signonsandiego1">{{cite news | last = Schemm | first = Paul | last2 = Michael | first2 = Maggie | agency = Associated Press | date = 2011-02-05 | url = http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/2011/feb/11/mubarak-leaves-cairo-for-sinai-as-protests-spread/ | title = Mubarak leaves Cairo for Sinai as protests spread | publisher = SignOnSanDiego.com | accessdate = 2011-02-12 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|publisher=Al Jazeera|title=Egypt's army vows smooth transition|date=February 12, 2011|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121217639448807.html|accessdate=February 13, 2011}}</ref> Massive protests continued in Cairo, Alexandria, and other cities. The presidential palace and parliament still remained surrounded by protestors and thousands of people surrounded the state TV building, keeping anyone from entering or leaving. The army issued a ''[[communiquÃ©]]'' in support of Mubarak's attempt to remain ''[[de jure]]'' president while delegating his powers to Vice President Suleiman.<ref>{{citation|title=Egyptian army backs Hosni Mubarak and calls for protesters to go home|ell by .25%url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/11/egyptian-army-backs-hosni-mubarak|first=Paul|last=Owen|date=2011/02/11|publisher=Guardian.co.uk}}</ref> Hossam Badrawi, the new secretary of the NDP, resigned from his position from the party due to his unhappiness with Hosni Mubarak's refusal to step down.<ref>[http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/02/11/latest-updates-on-day-18-of-egypt-protests/?hp "Latest Updates on Day 18 of Egypt Protests"] by Robert Mackey - ''The New York Times.'.' Retrieved 11 February 2011.</ref>
â
Demonstrators began to gather at new locations in Cairo. The army also surrounded the presidential palace and state television and radio buildings<ref name="aljazlive" /> as protesters surrounded the Egyptian radio and television union building demanding fair media coverage from state television. The state television shifted its attitude towards the protesters and begun referring to them as Jan25 Youth Revolution<!--is this precise?-->, admitting mistakes had been made in the media coverage of the protests: "We [the state TV] were under an information chaos," the news anchor stated. "We had strict orders from external sides."<ref>http://www.demotiximages.com/news/587341/egypts-joy-after-mubaraks-step-down</ref> There were also major protests in Alexandria and Mansoura. In [[Arish]], in north Sinai, the second police station in 24 hours came under heavy arms fire â including RPGs â in which at least one protester<!--need to add to total tally--> was killed and 20 injured, with possibly more police fatalities.<ref name="aljazlive" />
+
Demonstrators began to gather at new locations in Cairo. The army also surrounded the presidential palace and state television and radio buildings{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}} as protesters surrounded the Egyptian radio and television union building demanding fair media coverage from state television. The state television shifted its attitude towards the protesters and begun referring to them as Jan25 Youth Revolution<!--is this precise?-->, admitting mistakes had been made in the media coverage of the protests: "We [the state TV] were under an information chaos," the news anchor stated. "We had strict orders from external sides."<ref>http://www.demotiximages.com/news/587341/egypts-joy-after-mubaraks-step-down</ref> There were also major protests in Alexandria and Mansoura. In [[Arish]], in north Sinai, the second police station in 24 hours came under heavy arms fire â including RPGs â in which at least one protester<!--need to add to total tally--> was killed and 20 injured, with possibly more police fatalities.{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}}
==== Resignation of Mubarak ====
==== Resignation of Mubarak ====
[[File:Finally a free country.jpg|thumb|left|150 px|A protester holding a placard saying "''Finally: a free country.''"]]
[[File:Finally a free country.jpg|thumb|left|150 px|A protester holding a placard saying "''Finally: a free country.''"]]
â
Vice President Omar Suleiman announced from the Presidential Palace after 18:00 Cairo local time (GMT +2) on 11 February that the presidency had been vacated and the army council would run the country:<ref name="aljazlive" />
+
Vice President Omar Suleiman announced from the Presidential Palace after 18:00 Cairo local time (GMT +2) on 11 February that the presidency had been vacated and the army council would run the country:{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}}
Line 324: Line 324:
[[Mohammed ElBaradei]] told the ''Associated Press'' "This is the greatest day of my life. The country has been liberated after decades of repression," and he expects a "beautiful" transition of power.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110211/D9LAM4LO0.html |title=Mubarak resigns, hands power to military |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref> Mohammed El Baradei said that "Egypt is free."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.monstersandcritics.com/news/middleeast/news/article_1618774.php/ElBaradei-Egypt-is-a-free-and-proud-nation-Extra |title=ElBaradei: Egypt is a free and proud nation (Extra) |publisher=Monsters and Critics |date=2010-11-17 |accessdate=2011-02-14}}</ref> Various media outlets pointed out that this date was also the anniversary of the [[Islamic Revolution]], which occurred on 11 February 1979.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sify.com/news/iran-congratulates-egyptian-people-s-victory-news-international-lcmcacigiid.html |title=Iran congratulates Egyptian people's 'victory' |publisher=Sify.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-12}}</ref>
[[Mohammed ElBaradei]] told the ''Associated Press'' "This is the greatest day of my life. The country has been liberated after decades of repression," and he expects a "beautiful" transition of power.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110211/D9LAM4LO0.html |title=Mubarak resigns, hands power to military |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref> Mohammed El Baradei said that "Egypt is free."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.monstersandcritics.com/news/middleeast/news/article_1618774.php/ElBaradei-Egypt-is-a-free-and-proud-nation-Extra |title=ElBaradei: Egypt is a free and proud nation (Extra) |publisher=Monsters and Critics |date=2010-11-17 |accessdate=2011-02-14}}</ref> Various media outlets pointed out that this date was also the anniversary of the [[Islamic Revolution]], which occurred on 11 February 1979.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sify.com/news/iran-congratulates-egyptian-people-s-victory-news-international-lcmcacigiid.html |title=Iran congratulates Egyptian people's 'victory' |publisher=Sify.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-12}}</ref>
â
An [[exchange traded fund]] based on the Egyptian stock market listed at the [[NYSE Euronext]] increased by 5% following the announcement. Egyptian five-years [[credit default swaps]] fell by 0.25%. ''Al Arabiya'' reported that the military council said it would sack the cabinet and then dissolve parliament.<ref>Bloomberg. Breaking News.</ref> Celebrations and car honking was reported in Alexandria, as well as around Cairo.<ref name="aljazlive" /> The BBC reported celebratory gunfire in Gaza.
+
An [[exchange traded fund]] based on the Egyptian stock market listed at the [[NYSE Euronext]] increased by 5% following the announcement. Egyptian five-years [[credit default swaps]] fell by 0.25%. ''Al Arabiya'' reported that the military council said it would sack the cabinet and then dissolve parliament.<ref>Bloomberg. Breaking News.</ref> Celebrations and car honking was reported in Alexandria, as well as around Cairo.{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}} The BBC reported celebratory gunfire in Gaza{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}}.
[[CBS]] correspondent [[Lara Logan]] was covering the jubilation in Tahrir Square when she and her team were surrounded by a dangerous element amidst the celebration. She suffered a brutal and sustained sexual assault and beating before being saved by a group of women and an estimated 20 Egyptian soldiers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1357485/Lara-Logan-assault-Former-GMTV-reporter-suffers-sex-attack-covering-Egypt-uprising.html |title=Ex-GMTV reporter Lara Logan leaves hospital six days after Cairo mob sex-attack - and vows to be back at work within weeks |publisher=Dailymail.co.uk |date=2011-02-16 |accessdate=2011-02-20}}</ref>
